lines.text:
[remembering his last night at home, before leaving for France, as he finishes a glass of beer at a farewell party]
Ahhhhh. Beer isn't what it used to be.
I hope the French beer isn't what it used to be either. Remember the last time, Ted?
Yeah. I remember something even better than beer too.

[offering beer]
Anyone for any more?
No, thank you.

[looks at clock]
It's nearly twelve. We've got to be at the depot at seven.
[motions to his wife]
Come on home.
We'll have them both back before you can turn around. The war will be over by Christmas.
The war will be over by Christmas. Where have I heard *that* before?

[indicates sign for their construction business]
It's a shame we've got to close the business, Ted.
Why, it's this habit we've gotten into; fighting the same war every twenty years.
Nasty habit too.

[sees the camp approaching and decides he and his men will enter smartly]
March to attention!

[writing a letter home]
How do you spell "sufficient"?
Same as a Sergeant-Major's blessing. Two "f"'s and one "c".

[having a hard time adjusting to POW life after two months]
What a sucker I was, joining the ruddy Army. I pictured myself cutting it loose with some roundie old French dames. And here I am, shut up in this place until I'll be past it.
You should have joined the Navy and let the world see you.
[gently]
Now son, it's no use you blowing off. Take things as you find them. That's always been my motto. And the way I look at it...
Awwww. Drip! Drip! Drip! You burn me up. You're worse than a woman!

[warning]
Now, knock it sonny. I was swinging a rifle when your nappies were swinging on the line
I wonder how Jane is getting on these days?
Who's Jane? Your girl?
lines.character: Capt. Karel Hasek, alias Geoffrey Mitchell

lines.text: No, no. *The* Jane. The strip in the "Mirror".

[realizing he's made a mistake]
Oh, yes, the strip in the mirror.
lines.character: Capt. Karel Hasek, alias Geoffrey Mitchell

lines.text:
[discussing his escape plans with Horsfall and Evans]
Why, all I have to do is stow away in one of those garbage bins or something. Why, it's as easy as kiss your...
[sees Mitchell approach]
If you're planning an escape, Mathews, may I give you a piece of advice? Individual escapes hardly ever succeed. These things have to be very carefully planned and co-ordinated by a whole group.
lines.character: Capt. Karel Hasek, alias Geoffrey Mitchell

lines.text: All the same, sir, I'm going to have a go at it. If you have no objections!
Well... Good luck to you.
lines.character: Capt. Karel Hasek, alias Geoffrey Mitchell

lines.text: [walks off]
Good luck... Two-faced bleeder.
I don't know what it is, but there's something phony about that bloke.

[as Christmas of 1940 approaches]
Last Christmas I had my first concert. It was where I met Caroline.

Last Christmas I was in Dachau Concentration Camp. Christmas Eve a new batch of prisoners came in. One of them brought me news of my family. They'd been caught giving food to a Polish Jew. They were taken out and shot. My father, my mother, all of them.
lines.character: Capt. Karel Hasek, alias Geoffrey Mitchell

lines.text:
[awaits news about his prospective eye operation. Sits up as he hears the Padre come out of a room with a German doctor]
Well, lad, it's me again.
Yes, Padre?
David... They can't operate.

[stunned]
Not... ever?
No, David.
I won't ever see again?
[gets upset]
I don't believe it. It's that German doctor! When I get back to Scotland...
No! David, it's no use. You've got to face it.
I'll not need this any more.
[removes bandages from around eyes]

You feel now there's nothing left to live for. And that feeling will go on for a long time. But then you'll begin to remember things that are left. You'll begin to realize that this darkness of yours is not absolute. David, the things that make life worthwhile for all of us -kindness, affection, companionship. The loss of your sight can never rob you of those things, David. We're your friends here. We offer you our help and understanding. And waiting to welcome you home, when all this is over, are your own folk who love you.
I've had a letter, Don.
The mail's in? Perhaps there's a letter for me, with news of the baby.

[downcast]
There's no letter for you. There *is* news.
Flo's all right? Not them raids...?

She's OK. The letter's from her. Don, it's a baby girl. She's doing nice. Dillis... You'll hear it sooner or later. It seemed the doctor warned her about it being dangerous, because of her age. But she wouldn't be put off. Flo was with her at the end. It went quite quickly. Flo's gonna look after the baby until you get back.

[writing a letter to Celia in November of 1942]
"Our third winter is approaching, bringing with it a new enemy. It is not the duration but the indefiniteness of duration. For if a man knew the length of his sentence, he could plan accordingly. Afterwards in our memories, we shall relive only the sunny days. The pleasant scenes. The freedom of mind, and the comradeship. We shall forget the wet days... the wet weeks... Those days when it seemed an effort to do nothing and our bunks were the only release. Deep down in the hearts of all of us there dwells a lonely ache, a desperate yearning for those we love, and a fear. A fear of becoming forgotten men. Write to me again soon, Celia. You never know how great the comfort is that your letters bring. They give me strength, and hope, and happiness. You will never know how much they mean to me."
lines.character: Capt. Karel Hasek, alias Geoffrey Mitchell

lines.text:
[watches as Evans begins planting his vegetable garden in the spring of 1944]
Trying leeks again this year?
I was thinking of trying some asparagus.
Asparagus? That takes seven years, Don.

[sadly]
Aye.

[referring to the war]
I don't give it more than another year, meself.
Another year? Meredith will be four.
Flo's hair's gone all white, she says.
Everything's changing. Do you think we'll be able to pick it up? The business, and everything?
Search me. We're not as young as we were.
No. We're not as young as we were.
